study_scale: 1 common garden, 24 provenances from all over Canada
growth_metric: growth anomalies (e.g. Spring frost ring, late frost ring, wood density fluctuations, etc.)
authorsthink_evidence_gslbygrowth: unsure. the authors claim provenances from different areas showed very contrasting anomalies depending of heir origin. Pops from warmer showed more latewood anomalies consistent with more extensive use of growing season

study_scale: countrywide (all of Canada)
ifyouthink_no_why: they lump all effects of climate change  (including ""growing season length, net N mineralization,  N fixation"" together in their reporting so it is difficult to pull out only effects of increased GSL)
ifyes_whichexternal: N deposition, climate, gsl, CO2 fertilization
excellent_study: not excellent but interesting modelling study
notes:
interannual variations in the C balance 
of Canada's forests dominated by climate variability, whereas over the long term the effects of N  deposition and CO2 fertilization have accumulated to become substantial. During 1895-1996, N deposition was the largest contributor to the nondisturbance effects with a total  contribution of-42%, followed by climate change at -34% and CO2 fertilization at -19% (Table 2)

species_list: Betula pubescens, Picea abies,  Pinus sylvestris(for growth)
study_scale: tree rings from cores collected from 11 different sites in high latitude and treeline locations in northern Sweden; n per species was 3,4,10, respectively)
excellent_study: no. they measured phenology and compared it to tree ring data, but because they 1) used different species across phenology and tree ring components; and 2) did not use raw ring widths (instead using detrended indices that were correlated with different month's temperatures, rather than growing season length)
missing_something_major: they analyzed trends in start vs end of growing season separately, and these were analyzed separately from tree ring data. If these data had been integrated in a different way, the authors could have addressed our question

excellent_study: interesting!
missing_something_major: I'm not sure about assumptions of photosynthesis model…

teststatistic_where: Thus, phenology hardly contributed to explain the inter-annual variation in annual growth, whereas growth activity, particularly N daysgrowth, turned out to be the most important predictor in the LMM, explaining 65% to 88% of the inter- annual variation (Table S3, Figure S8).

excellent_study: This is a very important study for us as they have data on lots of our surrounding questions, but their 'dredge' approach the analyses is diffiucult to interpret.
missing_something_major: leaf phenology
notes: They find that they number of days plants grow (growth>0) is more related to growth than the end-start dates of growth. This feels more tautilogical than they admit.

study_scale: 9 populations along an elevational gradient of 1500 m in the French
study_level: across sites/populations across years within individuals
ifyouthink_no_why: there is no correlation between longer growing seasons and increased ring width
excellent_study: pretty close - it would be great if they had more species and across more locations
missing_something_major: no
notes: they found no relationship between phenology and radial growth
notes_specific_columns: but they found that higher temps at higher elevations lead to increased radial growth, whereas higher temps at lower elevations decreased growth, likely due to water availability

study_scale: Pyrenees

species_list: Abies alba, Acer pseudoplatanus, Fagus sylvatica, Fraxinus excelsior, Ilex aquifolium, Quercus petraea
study_scale: seeds on average from 9 provenances for each species (ranging from 6-13 depending on species) located along 2 elevational gradients in the Pyrenees (French side), planted in 1 common garden at sea level in SW France
rep_number: Average of 25 individual seedlings per provenance (meaning 150+ seedlings per species)
gsl_metric: plant vegetative phenology (budburst, leafout); specifically period between leaf unfolding and senescence
authorsthink_evidence_gslbygrowth: yes (for 2 of six species (beech and oak). Not significant for the other four species.
excellent_study: No, but primarily because their goal wasn't to explore the link between growing season and length but to understand how provenances differ in their growth and phenology in a common location (with all individuals experiending the same climate). This they were able to do well.
missing_something_major: In an ideal world, it would have been cool to replicate their common garden in a lot of different places, so they could explore how climatic differences (across sites) interact with local adaptation (provenance) to climate to control growth. Or manipulating climate with warming and watering, to explose the same provenances to longer growing seasons and / or differences in water availability would also have been cool

species_list: Abies alba, Acer pseudoplatanus, Fagus sylvatica, Fraxinus excelsior, Ilex aquifolium, Quercus petraea
study_scale: seeds on average from 9 provenances for each species (ranging from 6-13 depending on species) located along 2 elevational gradients in the Pyrenees (French side), planted in 1 common garden at sea level in SW France
rep_number: Average of 25 individual seedlings per provenance (meaning 150+ seedlings per species)
gsl_metric: plant vegetative phenology (budburst, leafout); specifically leaf unfolding
authorsthink_evidence_gslbygrowth: yes (for 2 of six species (fir and holly) earlier leaf unfolding led to greater growth, for one species earlier leaf unfolding led to less growth (leaf unfolding unrelated to growth for the other three species).
excellent_study: No, but primarily because their goal wasn't to explore the link between growing season and length but to understand how provenances differ in their growth and phenology in a common location (with all individuals experiending the same climate). This they were able to do well.
missing_something_major: In an ideal world, it would have been cool to replicate their common garden in a lot of different places, so they could explore how climatic differences (across sites) interact with local adaptation (provenance) to climate to control growth. species_list: Abies alba, Acer pseudoplatanus, Fagus sylvatica, Fraxinus excelsior, Ilex aquifolium, Quercus petraea
study_scale: seeds on average from 9 provenances for each species (ranging from 6-13 depending on species) located along 2 elevational gradients in the Pyrenees (French side), planted in 1 common garden at sea level in SW France
rep_number: Average of 25 individual seedlings per provenance (meaning 150+ seedlings per species)
gsl_metric: plant vegetative phenology (budburst, leafout); specifically leaf senescence
authorsthink_evidence_gslbygrowth: yes for 2 of six species (sycamore and beech), later leaf senescence led to greater growth. However later leaf senescence led to less growth for 1 species (oak). The other three species did not demonstrate a correlation between senescence and growth.
excellent_study: No, but primarily because their goal wasn't to explore the link between growing season and length but to understand how provenances differ in their growth and phenology in a common location (with all individuals experiending the same climate). This they were able to do well.
missing_something_major: In an ideal world, it would have been cool to replicate their common garden in a lot of different places, so they could explore how climatic differences (across sites) interact with local adaptation (provenance) to climate to control growth. Or manipulating climate with warming and watering, to explose the same provenances to longer growing seasons and / or differences in water availability would also have been cool

study_scale: Northern hemisphere
study_level: across years within pixels (500 m pixels from 2001-2018 :MODIS)
growth_metric: photosynthesis (from daily photosynthesis calculated from the LPJ and P models, summed per month)
ifyouthink_no_why: they did not explore link between GSL and growth, instead, looked at the relationship between photosynthetic activity (growth) and EOS. So no because they did not explore GSL (although they could have) and because they switched the explanatory and response variables.
ifyes_whichendogenous: activity pre vs. post solstice (growth and temperature pre solstice advances EOS, while growth and temperature post solstice delays it - suggesting there is some sort of developmental switch in effects)
excellent_study: No. There are some really interesting patterns and lots of data, but in the end quite frustrating because there is a lot that isn't measured and in some cases could have been. The Zohner paper is really relevant to understanding how climate influences the end of season (EOS), as defined by remote sensing data (greenness declines in northern forests), the timing of leaf abscission / senescence (from phenological observations), and the decline of chlorophyll content in leaves of beech. However, they don't directly explore temperature effects or growth responses, but instead explore the effects of photosynthesis / productivity pre and post solstic on EOS... Of course, satellite data and PEP data also don't include growth measurements, so that would have been tough (although maybe they could have done something clever with NDVI integrated under the curve, or with ITRDB data for the PEP analysis), but they coudl certainly have done a better job with their experiment. They also focus entirely on EOS, so it's not always clear how the entire growing season length changes. They do use estimates of photosynthesis to calculate GPP, but they use it as an explanatory rather than a response variable.
missing_something_major: I really wished they had looked at the entire length of the growing season rather than just EOS. And I wish they had explored how GSL linked to GPP or photosynthesis (so explored GSL, and looked at GPP as a response rather than an explanatory variable)
notes: check figures 2, 3, 4, 5 in the manuscript

species_list: Aesculus hippocastanum, Betula pendula, Fagus sylvatic, Quercus robur
study_scale: Germany, Switzerland, Austria
rep_number: 12759 total individual time series (~3000 per species)
growth_metric: NDVI and GPP (gross primary productivity) from MODIS

The Zohner paper is really relevant to understanding how climate influences the end of season (EOS), as defined by remote sensing data (greenness declines in northern forests), the timing of leaf abscission / senescence (from phenological observations), and the decline of chlorophyll content in leaves of beech. However, they don't directly explore temperature effects or growth responses, but instead explore the effects of photosynthesis / productivity pre and post solstic on EOS... Of course, satellite data and PEP data also don't include growth measurements, so that would have been tough (although maybe they could have done something clever with NDVI integrated under the curve, or with ITRDB data for the PEP analysis), but they coudl certainly have done a better job with their experiment. They also focus entirely on EOS, so it's not always clear how the entire growing season length changes. They do use estimates of photosynthesis to calculate GPP, but they use it as an explanatory rather than a response variable.
missing_something_major: I really wished they had looked at the entire length of the growing season rather than just EOS.

study_scale: CHN Terrace / central low elevation Switzerland (outdoors)
rep_number: 140 saplings in the whole experiment (14 in each treatment, 38 in control, 9 treatments)
ifyouthink_no_why: they did not explore link between GSL and growth, instead, looked at the relationship between photosynthetic activity (growth) and EOS. So no because they did not explore GSL (although they could have) and because they switched the explanatory and response variables.
ifyes_whichendogenous: activity pre vs. post solstice (growth and temperature pre solstice advances EOS, while growth and temperature post solstice delays it - suggesting there is some sort of developmental switch in effects)
excellent_study: No. There are some really interesting patterns and lots of data, but in the end quite frustrating because there is a lot that isn't measured and in some cases could have been. The Zohner paper is really relevant to understanding how climate influences the end of season (EOS), as defined by remote sensing data (greenness declines in northern forests), the timing of leaf abscission / senescence (from phenological observations), and the decline of chlorophyll content in leaves of beech. However, they don't directly explore temperature effects or growth responses, but instead explore the effects of photosynthesis / productivity pre and post solstic on EOS... Of course, satellite data and PEP data also don't include growth measurements, so that would have been tough (although maybe they could have done something clever with NDVI integrated under the curve, or with ITRDB data for the PEP analysis), but they coudl certainly have done a better job with their experiment. They do use estimates of photosynthesis to calculate GPP, but they use it as an explanatory rather than a response variable.
missing_something_major: They could have measured SOS and growth (height or diameter), a real missed opportunity. I also question the choice of just one species, and FASY in particular

species_list: This was an ecosystem level study in the NE USA (Harvard Forest), probably included a lot of Quercus rubra and prinus, Acer rubrum and possibly saccharum, Tsuga canadensis, Pinus strobus
study_scale: 100's of plots at Harvard Forest, in four different locations collectively covering ~ 40 km2
rep_number: many plots, 100's of trees (and other measurements) went into estimates of NEP and GPP of 3 different sites
growth_metric: NEP and GPP (net ecosystem production and gross primary production)
gsl_start_metric: onset ecosystem productivity (first day daily NEP falls above 30% of maximum)
gsl_end_metric: end ecosystem productivity (first day daily NEP falls below 30% of maximum after onset)
authorsthink_ALTteststatistic:: They found that an earlier onset of vegetative growth increased spring NEP (2 sites, EMS, HEM), and a later EOS increased autumn NEP (1 site, EMS). They used these values to calculate how much more ANPP was observed in one site (EMS) due to a GSL increase. See figure 13a-d, page 19. They also found that the duration of the growing season increased over time at one site (EMS fig. 12) and that NEP had also increased over time at this site (fig 7d). See page 27 for a discussion of this
teststatistic_where: figure 13, also fig 12, fig 7, see page 19
excellent_study: No. Their goal was not to look for growing season length - growth relationships, but because they were interested in understanding the carbon budget and how it changed over time, they did end up pulling together a lot of the same data. They found a lot of trends with time that suggested increasing GSL is causing increasing growth (e.g. time by GPP, time by GSL), so they could have put it together but they didn't
missing_something_major: I wish they had directly quantified the relationship between growing season length (as they defined from NEP) and GPP, they assumed it from time-GPP and time-GSL, as well as SOS spring NEP and EOS autumn NEP relationships… They also had some information on SOS and EOS from long-term phenological observations of 9 trees, and I think they could have done more with that if they also had growth rates (see page 10, figs. 9 and 11)
simple.growth.metric: NEP and GPP (net ecosystem production and gross primary production)
